OVERVIEW: The Lynch series consists of moderately deep, well drained slow or very slowly permeable soils formed in clay residuum weathered from calcareous and gypsiferous shale.  These upland soils have slopes ranging from 2 to 30 percent.  Mean annual temperature is about 49 degrees F, and mean annual precipitation is about 22 inches.

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine, smectitic, mesic Typic Haplustepts

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Lynch silty clay - on an 8 percent convex west-facing slope in a cultivated field.  When described the soil was dry throughout.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise stated.)
Ap--0 to 4 inches; dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) silty clay, very dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) moist; weak fine granular structure; slightly hard friable; many fine and medium roots; strong effervescence mildly alkaline; abrupt smooth boundary.  (3 to 6 inches thick)
A--4 to 8 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) clay, dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) moist; weak coarse subangular blocky structure parting to weak medium and fine subangular; hard, firm but crumbly; many very fine and few fine roots; strong effervescence mildly alkaline; abrupt wavy boundary.  (0 to 8 inches thick)
BA--8 to 14 inches; light olive brown (2.5Y 5/4) silty clay, olive brown (2.5Y 4/4) moist; weak coarse subangular blocky structure parting to moderate medium and fine angular blocky; hard, firm; few fine and medium roots; strong effervescence; moderately alkaline; gradual smooth boundary.  (0 to 6 inches thick)
Bw--14 to 28 inches; light yellowish brown to light olive brown (2.5Y 5/4) clay; olive brown (2.5Y 4/4) moist; weak coarse prismatic structure parting to moderate fine angular blocky; very hard, very firm; few fine roots; strong effervescence; moderately alkaline; smooth boundary.  (6 to 15 inches thick)
C--28 to 33 inches; light yellowish brown (2.5Y 6/4) clay; light olive brown (2.5Y 5/4) moist; massive; hard, firm; few very fine roots moving between parallel shale plates; many fine shale fragments; common lime and gypsum crystals interspersed with clay; strong effervescence mildly alkaline; gradual smooth boundary.  (3 to 15 inches thick)
Cr--33 to 60 inches; pale yellow (2.5Y 7/4) bedded shale; light olive brown (2.5Y 5/4) moist; massive breaking to moderate medium and coarse platy fragments; hard, firm; few very fine roots between parallel shale plates; many lime and gypsum and lime crystals in seams; strong effervescence; mildly alkaline.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Boyd County, Nebraska; about 1/2 mile south of Bristow; 2112 feet north, 200 feet east of the southwest corner, sec. 14, T. 33 N., R. 11 W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The solum typically is 17 to 35 inches thick, and the depth to soft, partially weathered shale is 20 to 40 inches.  In addition to the lime, the parent material and shale contains 30 to 40 percent gypsum in seams and pockets.  It is mildly alkaline to strongly alkaline.
The A horizon has hue of 10YR or 2.5Y, value of 4 through 6 and 2 through 4 moist, and chroma of 2 or 3.  Silty clay is the dominant texture of the A horizon, but due to the gypsum, the soil feels coarser textured.  In some pedons the A horizon is lacking.
The B horizon has hue of 10YR or 2.5Y, value of 4 through 7 and 3 through 6 moist and chroma of 2 to 4.  The B horizon is clay or silty clay.
Some pedons have a BC horizon.
The C horizon has hue of 2.5Y or 5Y, value of 6 through 8 and 4 through 6 moist, and chroma to 2 through 6.
The Cr horizon has hue of 2.5Y or 5Y, value of 6 through 8 and 4 through 6 moist, and chroma of 1through 4.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  Corinth is the only other series in this family.  Corinth soils do not contain as much gypsum in the subsoil and parent material as Lynch soils.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEORGRAPHIC SETTING:  The Lynch soils are on gently sloping to steep uplands.  Slopes range from 2 to 30 percent.  They formed in clay residuum weathered from calcareous and gypsiferous, light colored, soft shales.  The average annual precipitation ranges from about 20 to 24 inches.  The average annual air temperature ranges from about 47 to 52 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Boyd, Bristow, Lakoma, Sansarc, and Verdel soils.  Boyd and Lakoma soils have developed in dark shales, and occur above Lynch soils.  Bristow and Sansarc soils are less than 20 inches to bedrock and occur above Lynch.  Verdel soils have vertic characteristics and are on terrace positions.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; surface runoff is medium on the 3 to 7 percent slopes, and rapid on slopes greater than 7 percent.  Permeability is slow or very slow.  After dry periods, cracks make initial intake rapid.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Cropland and rangeland.  The less sloping areas are mostly in cropland; small grains, sorghum, and alfalfa are the principal crops.  The more sloping areas are in native range; the vegetation consists of mid and tall grasses.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  North-central Nebraska and south-central South Dakota.  These soils are of moderate extent, and are confined to light colored shale outcrop areas along the Missouri River and its tributaries.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Denver, Colorado

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Laboratory sample numbers 77P0220-77P0225.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
